Rank Hyperparameter Tuning Results

Source: R/tune-tk_tune_parameters.R
tk_tune_rank_parameters.Rd

tk_tune_rank_parameters() returns the tuning performance results from functions like tune::tune_grid(). If possible, adds parameter ranking results based on metric performance, model failure rates, and standard error (variability).

tk_tune_rank_parameters(.data, .metric, .max_failure_rate = 1)

Arguments

.data

A tibble of class "tune_results"
.metric

Select a metric to use for tuning performance investigation.
.max_failure_rate

Range (0,1). Use to .max_failure_rate to filter models below an acceptable failure threshold.

Value

A tibble or data.frame with ranked tuning parameters.

Details

Metric Ranking (Model Accuracy)

The model with the lowest (best) rank is that with the lowest mean error.

Failure Rate Ranking (Robustness to New Data)

Models with lower failure rates are more robust to new data. Failure rate rank is a score based on the proportion of models that failed during tuning.

  • Calculation: Failure Rate = n / No. of Resample Slices

  • Models with a non-zero failure rate have a higher likelihood of failing on new data and are therefore less robust.

Standard Error Ranking (Model Variability)

Models with lower standard error are more consistent (less variability).

Examples

library(dplyr)
library(tune)
library(timetk)

arima_workflow_tuned %>%
    tk_tune_rank_parameters(.max_failure_rate = 1)
#> Using .metric = 'mae'
#> # A tibble: 50 x 15
#>        p     d     q     P     D     Q .metric .estimator  mean     n std_err
#>    <int> <int> <int> <int> <int> <int> <chr>   <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl>
#>  1     3     1     2     2     0     2 mae     standard    142.     1   NA   
#>  2     2     1     1     2     0     2 mae     standard    142.     1   NA   
#>  3     4     1     4     1     0     1 mae     standard    183.     2  108.  
#>  4     2     1     1     1     0     1 mae     standard    190.     2  117.  
#>  5     2     1     2     1     0     1 mae     standard    190.     2  117.  
#>  6     2     0     3     0     1     0 mae     standard    203.     2   43.5 
#>  7     1     0     4     1     0     0 mae     standard    207.     2    3.09
#>  8     3     0     1     1     0     0 mae     standard    214.     2    1.50
#>  9     3     0     4     1     0     1 mae     standard    224.     2   40.5 
#> 10     3     1     5     1     0     2 mae     standard    225.     2  151.  
#> # … with 40 more rows, and 4 more variables: failure_rate <dbl>,
#> #   .rank_metric <int>, .rank_failure_rate <int>, .rank_std_err <int>
